text: Linda Ronstadt, who left an indelible mark on the classic-rock era, reflects on her career: “It was best when I forgot about everything and just thought about the music.” https://t.co/wX2qrZuWHl

text: Rare varieties discovered by Rancho Gordo’s Steve Sando have turned the humble legume into a gourmet food. https://t.co/bePFegghBM

text: "I could not believe how much happier I was now that I had Merle in my life," Sarah Miller writes, about her adopted blue heeler. "Then she started to slow down." https://t.co/g5qg8z0p4k

name: NewYorker
text: Frog and Toad are “of the same sex, and they love each other,” the daughter of its author, Arnold Lobel, said. “It was quite ahead of its time in that respect.” https://t.co/GneZn1XhFj

text: Ingeborg Bachmann’s novel “Malina” is one of the great portraits of a mind at work, and the movie adaptation distills the tangled turbulence of its protagonist’s mind with extraordinary discernment. https://t.co/dYEGl3B3Fu

name: NewYorker
text: Personal-productivity systems like Getting Things Done don’t address the insidiously haphazard way that work unfolds at the organizational level; they only help individuals cope with its effects. https://t.co/FlUFyMnQgb

name: NewYorker
text:

text: Mitch McConnell has pointed to his obstruction of Merrick Garland's hearing with pride, saying, “The most important decision I’ve made in my political career was the decision not to do something.” https://t.co/tUA2qM7ry8

name: NewYorker
text: President Trump’s refusal to concede defeat is terrible for democracy, but ultimately a bad case of Trumpian bluster rather than an ominous portent of tanks in the streets. https://t.co/HwTnN5ebb4

name: NewYorker
text: The F.D.A. is responsible for approving vaccines, and, although its leadership has been bullied and weakened by President Trump, the group within the agency that has evaluated vaccines for decades has no such taint. https://t.co/RSdKgkiHBL

text: Joe Biden won Nevada and Arizona, but the Democratic Party must appeal to more Latino voters if it wants to win consistently in Sun Belt states. https://t.co/jyjNwMM2JZ

name: NewYorker
text: Toby Ord, a philosopher who studies our species’ collective fate, considers both the grim futures that await us if existential threats to humanity aren’t addressed and the far more promising outcomes that become possible if they are. https://t.co/UVsek0tcvF

text: When the pandemic hit, the coronavirus eviscerated Haredi communities like the one in Borough Park. Yet hundreds of Haredi Jews have taken to the streets in protest of public-health restrictions. https://t.co/quA8zastlx

name: NewYorker
text: Richard Renaldi’s portraits of fast-food workers are formal and exalted, like 19th-century studio portraiture. “I love the way that, with the view camera, you stop and you see the subject—you see each other,” he says. https://t.co/MX1jEAmWaR
